Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Super-resolution Fluorescence Microscope

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1337804
Payne

Super-resolution fluorescence microscopy provides 20 nm resolution using visible light. This
level of resolution allows scientists and engineers to investigate cells, organelles, viruses,
and nanoparticles on their relevant length scale. A group of 23 Georgia Tech faculty members
in 7 departments propose to acquire a Zeiss LSM 780 Elyra PS1 Combi super-resolution fluorescence
microscope to advance research along 3 themes; Cellular & Engineering Bioscience, Complex
Systems, and Nanoscience. The microscope will be part of the Georgia Tech core facilities
located in the Parker H. Petit Institute for Bioengineering and Bioscience (IBB). These core
facilities are available to any academic or industry researcher and we expect the super-resolution
microscope will be a valuable tool for researchers throughout the Southeast. The core facilities
also provide professional staff to oversee maintenance and training, as well as long-term
stewardship of the microscope. In addition to advances in research, this microscope will be
a valuable educational tool for high school students, undergraduates, graduate students, and
postdoctoral researchers, both at Georgia Tech and in Atlanta.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Super-resolution fluorescence microscopy provides <250 nm spatial resolution using visible light. Sometimes referred to as “breaking the diffraction limit,” this discovery was awarded the 2014 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. This level of resolution allows scientists and engineers to investigate cells, organelles, viruses, and nanoparticles on their relevant length scale. This NSF grant supported the purchase of a super-resolution fluorescence microscope for the core facilities at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta, Georgia. These core facilities are available to any academic or industry researcher. Since the installation in 2014, researchers in the fields of Biology, Chemistry & Biochemistry, Biomedical Engineering, Materials Science, Physics, and Medicine have used the microscope. Their research will impact society through advances in human health, understanding the origins of life, and new lithographic techniques. High school students at four Atlanta public schools experienced the excitement of this research by using the super-resolution microscope as part of Project ENGAGES (Engaging New Generations at Georgia Tech Engineering & Sciences), led by the Parker H. Petit Institute for Bioengineering and Bioscience. This is a comprehensive multi-year mentoring program that first trains the selected students in basic lab techniques and then pairs them with a graduate student mentor. The graduate students themselves are selected as mentors based on a proposed project and their academic record. The project must be aimed at the high school level and allow students to work towards independence over a 1 year period. These high school students, along with undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers have the unique opportunity to use super-resolution fluorescence microscopy to help advance their research, while also being trained in this new technology.
